newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore Dec gas oil/jet spread slumps to $1.50.
newsitem.headline: Singapore Dec gas oil/jet spread slumps to $1.50.

text.p: The December gas oil/jet fuel swap spread (regrade) was quoted on Tuesday at a low of $1.30/$1.55 on a huge stock build in China, Guam, Singapore and the Middle East, industry sources said.
About two months ago, the December regrade traded at $4.25 but now it has plummetted to around $1.50 on ample stocks and record price of gas oil, one trader said.
"Is the low regrade because of the weakness of jet or the strength of gas oil?" asked one trader.
The answer most traders say is due to both.
Physical gas oil in Singapore, currently trading around the five-year high mark of $30.55 a barrel due to low distillate stocks in the U.S. and Europe has caused the regrade to narrow.
Asian gas oil prices were dragged up on the back of record Western prices which attracted Middle East cargoes. These cargoes were traditionally sold to Asia.
Jet fuel did not keep pace with the increases seen on gas oil as jet demand was relatively weaker and as a result the regrade crunched, one trader said.
Sources estimated that oil trading firms and refiners have stored about five million barrels of jet fuel at independent terminals in Asia on expectations of strong winter demand.
But winter demand has yet to materialise and as a result there's strong downward pressure on prices, traders said.
The regrade is traditional at its widest in December and January due to peak winter demand for jet-kerosene fuel as a burning fuel in North Asia.
Last winter, the December regrade traded at a peak of nearly $5.00, a broker said.
Jet fuel prices skyrocketted last December after unexpected refinery shutdowns in Indonesia and India, and Japanese refiners cutting operating rates by between five and 10 percent, one trader said.
But this year there are no such news and supplies have improved substantially as a result of the start up of new refineries in Thailand and South Korea, he said.
Although the regrade has crunched, the price of prompt physical jet fuel is still relatively high at above $30.00 per barrel free-on-board (fob) Singapore due to high crude prices, traders said.
At this time last year, prompt physical jet fuel was trading between $22.50 and $23.00 per barrel fob Singapore.
Most traders said that because jet fuel prices are already quiet high and gas oil is expected to remain firm, it is not likely that the regrade will change substantially.
